section.title: Graphs of Relations on a Set

introduction.p: In this section we introduce directed graphs as a way to visualize relations on a set.

subsection.title: Digraphs
subsection.p: Let A = \{0, 1,2,3\}, and let R = \{(0, 0), (0, 3), (1, 2), (2, 1), (3, 2), (2, 0)\} In representing this relation as a graph, elements of A are called the vertices of the graph. They are typically represented by labeled points or small circles. We connect vertex a to vertex b with an arrow, called an edge, going from vertex a to vertex b if and only if a R b. This type of graph of a relation R is called a directed graph or digraph. is a digraph for R. Notice that since 0 is related to itself, we draw a self-loop at 0.Directed graphDigraph

The actual location of the vertices in a digraph is immaterial. The actual location of vertices we choose is called an embedding of a graphEmbedding of a graph. The main idea is to place the vertices in such a way that the graph is easy to read. After drawing a rough-draft graph of a relation, we may decide to relocate the vertices so that the final result will be neater. could also be presented as in .

subsection.p: A vertex of a graph is also called a node, point, or a junction. An edge of a graph is also referred to as an arc, a line, or a branch. Do not be concerned if two graphs of a given relation look different as long as the connections between vertices are the same in two graphs.
